question: Question_08
statement:
Let

\[A = \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 0 & 3 \\ 0 & 3 & 0 \\ 4 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right]\]

Find a diagonal matrix \emph{D} and an invertible matrix \emph{P} such
that $A = PDP^{-1}$. Do not compute the matrix $P^{-1}$. Show that
$A^{-k}$ approaches the zero matrix as \emph{k} becomes very large.
sols:
To find the diagonal matrix \emph{D}, we need to compute the determinant
of the matrix \emph{A-tI}.

\begin{align*}
\det(A-tI) &= \det\left(\left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
2-t & 0 & 3 \\ 
0 & 3-t & 0 \\ 
4 & 0 & 1-t\\ 
\end{array} \right] \right) \\
& = (3-t)\det\left(\left[ \begin{array}{cc}
2-t & 3  \\ 
4 & 1-t
\end{array} \right] \right)\\
&= (3-t)\left( (2-t)(1-t) - 12 \right)    \\
& = (3-t)(t-5)(t+2)
\end{align*}

Which means that eigenvalues are 3, 5 and -2. To find the eigenvectors
(which will be the columns of the matrix \emph{P}), we pick vectors of
the kernels of $A-tI$ where \emph{t} = 3, 5, -2.

\textbf{Eigenvalue \emph{t} = 3.}

\[\left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
2-3 & 0 & 3 \\ 
0 & 3-3 & 0 \\ 
4 & 0 & 1-3\\ 
\end{array} \right]  = \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
-1 & 0 & 3 \\ 
0 & 0 & 0 \\ 
4 & 0 & -2\\ 
\end{array} \right]\] Thus an eigenvector corresponding to the
eigenvalue \emph{t} = 3 is given by

\[\left[ \begin{array}{c}
0 \\ 
1 \\ 
0 
\end{array} \right]\]

\textbf{Eigenvalue \emph{t} = 5.}

\[\left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
2-5 & 0 & 3 \\ 
0 & 3-5 & 0 \\ 
4 & 0 & 1-5\\ 
\end{array} \right]  = \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
-3 & 0 & 3 \\ 
0 & -2 & 0 \\ 
4 & 0 & -4\\ 
\end{array} \right]\] Thus an eigenvector corresponding to the
eigenvalue \emph{t} = 5 is given by

\[\left[ \begin{array}{c}
1 \\ 
0 \\ 
1 
\end{array} \right]\]

\textbf{Eigenvalue \emph{t} = -2.}

\[\left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
2-(-2) & 0 & 3 \\ 
0 & 3-(-2) & 0 \\ 
4 & 0 & 1-(-2)\\ 
\end{array} \right]  = \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
4 & 0 & 3 \\ 
0 & 5 & 0 \\ 
4 & 0 & 3\\ 
\end{array} \right]\] Thus an eigenvector corresponding to the
eigenvalue \emph{t} = -2 is given by

\[\left[ \begin{array}{c}
3 \\ 
0 \\ 
-4 
\end{array} \right]\] can be chosen as an eigenvector.

So the matrices \emph{D} and \emph{P} are given by

\[D = \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
3 & 0 & 0  \\ 0 & 5 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -2
\end{array}\right] \quad P = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
0 & 1 & 3 \\ 
1 & 0 & 0 \\ 
0 & 1 & -4\\ 
\end{array} \right]\]

Now, as $A = PDP^{-1}$, then

\begin{align*}
A^{-k} &= \left( PDP^{-1} \right)^{-k}\\
 &= PD^{-k}P^{-1} \\
& = P\left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
3 & 0 & 0 \\ 
0 & 5 & 0 \\ 
0 & 0 & -2\\ 
\end{array} \right]^{-k}P^{-1}\\ 
& = P\left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
3^{-k} & 0 &  0\\ 
0 & 5^{-k} & 0 \\ 
0 & 0 & (-2)^{-k}\\ 
\end{array} \right]P^{-1}
\end{align*}

So we can see that as \emph{k} gets large, $D^{-k}$ get closers to the
zero matrix. Hence the right hand side, and with it the matrix
\emph{A}\textsubscript{-\emph{k}}, also approaches the zeros matrix.
hints:
You first need to compute the eigenvalues and eigenvectors for the
matrix. How will you then package them together to find \emph{P} and
\emph{D}?

For the second part, use that

\[\displaystyle
A^{-k} = (PDP^{-1})^{-k}\] Then expand and simplify the right hand side.
